contenido.en:
The Bible reveals that a select group of faithful individualsâ€”the 144,000â€”will receive the extraordinary responsibility of reigning with Jesus Christ in heaven as kings and priests.

ğŸ”¹ Why is it no longer literal Israel?
In ancient times, the nation of Israel was Godâ€™s exclusive people, but their position changed when they rejected the promised Messiah.
Jesus said in Matthew 23:37-38: â€œJerusalem... how often I wanted to gather your children... but you were not willing. Look! Your house is abandoned to you.â€
Godâ€™s favor shifted from literal Israel to a new â€œspiritual Israelâ€: people from all nations who would demonstrate faith in Christ.

ğŸ”¹ To whom was the promise to reign with Christ made?
The promise to reign with Christ in heaven was made to a small group: the 144,000 anointed with holy spirit.
Revelation 14:1-3 and 20:6 show that these kings and priests will be with Jesus ruling from heaven.
Not everyone goes to heaven. Most have a different hope: to live forever on Earth.

ğŸ”¹ What hope does the rest of humanity have?
Revelation 7:9-10 speaks of a 'great crowd' that will be saved and will live on Earth under God's Kingdom.
The promise of everlasting life on Earth was made to this large, obedient group.

ğŸ”¹ Is the number 144,000 literal?
The number is mentioned as exact in Revelation 7:4 and contrasted with an uncountable great crowd (verse 9).
This indicates the number is literal: a select, counted group.

ğŸ”¹ What do the 12,000 per tribe mean?
The tribes do not match those of literal Israel. They represent spiritual Israel.
The total of 144,000 is literal, but the tribal language is symbolic.

ğŸ”¹ What logic supports that only 144,000 will reign?
Every efficient government has few leaders. A limited number rules over many.
Jesus will be the principal King; the 144,000 will be his kings and priests (Revelation 5:10).

ğŸ”¹ What was always God's purpose?
God created humans to live on Earth, not in heaven (Genesis 1:28; Isaiah 45:18).
The heavenly Kingdom will restore that original purpose.

ğŸ”¹ Final Reflection
Which promise do you desire: to reign with Christ or to live forever on Earth?
Both promises are part of God's loving purpose.
